bibl.title: Despatch from Charles H. J. Taylor to James D. Porter, July 1, 1887
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

div1.p: U.S. Consulate General Monrovia Liberia July 1st, 1887
Chas. H. J. Taylor to Hon. Jas. D. Porter
Transit from Wyandotte Kas, to Liberia taking 49 days, 43 days of which was in actual travel and the other 6, caused by necessary delay. Praying permission to draw for
No. 6. U.S. Consulate Monrovia Liberia July 1st 1887
Hon Jas D. Porter oc oc oc oc Washington D. C.

Sir: I have the honor to call your attention to my no (1) Consular series, of date May 31st. You will find therein an account of my Transit from Wyandotte Kas., to Monrovia, consuming 49 days, I have drawn drafts on Secretary of States, as stated for 43 days of said time. I desire to respectfully call your attention to section 47 of the Consular reg. for '81, which I think justifies me in drawing for the other six (6) days at the rate

of $5000 per . I was forced to remain in Liverpool at the time I arrived there until the departure of (the Elder Dempster rco's steamship) the Roquelle. You will find that the Roquelle does not cull at Monrovia, but did so on their outward trip, at the time mentioned out of respect to the U.S. Government. If I had waited for steamer calling at Monrovia, I would not have arrived until June 7th instead of May 30th 1887. I hope that you may see that this added time, to the Hon. Secretary of States' maximum amount schedule, was caused by circumstances wholly beyond my control and therefore approve my "draft" for the am't of $82.42 waking the totla am't for "transit" $673.08.
I am your obedient servant re., Chas H. J. Taylor U.S. Consulate Gen'l
